(CBS) QUOTE OF THE DAY
“I had an epiphany a few years ago where I was out at a celebrity 
      party and it suddenly dawned on me that I had yet to meet a celebrity who 
      is as smart and interesting as any of my friends.” - Moby

SATURDAY ON 48 HOURS 
      MYSTERY 9PM/8C Here's a preview from Erin Moriarty 
      about Saturday's 48 Hours Mystery, DEATH OF A 
      DREAM: "I have never quite believed the 
      theory that "anyone" is capable of committing murder. With most killers, 
      you usually detect a problem in their childhood or a personality defect 
      that causes that person to choose to take the ultimate action against 
      another human being. But what would lead a young man with no history of 
      violence to do something so out of character? It is just one of the 
      mysteries that surrounds the murder of 21-year-old Catherine Woods. 
      First, some background: Catherine Woods was a stunning and 
      talented young woman, from my hometown of Columbus, Ohio, who moved to New 
      York with hopes of becoming a dancer and singer on Broadway. As the 
      daughter of the well-known director of the Ohio State University Marching 
      Band, Catherine was used to the spotlight and dreamed of her own name in 
      lights along the Great White Way. But, three years later, on November 
      27th, 2005, she was found stabbed to death in her apartment. Initially, 
      police focused on two suspects, neither of which fits the profile of a 
      killer. They are both young, aspiring musicians with no criminal records. 
      Catherine's murder was exceptionally brutal which makes it all the more 
      difficult to believe that either man could have done it and yet, one was 
      arrested, charged and tried for her murder. In this week's program 
      Death of a Dream, we investigate the evidence and follow the trial 
      that ends with a dramatic and surprising verdict. It is a case that will 
      remind you, as so many of our cases do, how a single, senseless act in a 
      moment of passion, can have drastic consequences for so many." - 
      Erin Moriarty 48 Hours Mystery airs Saturday at 
      10pmET/9CT) If you would like more information on any of these 
      stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail 
      us at: 48hours@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWS Here's an early look 
      at what we are working on for tonight's broadcast of the CBS EVENING NEWS 
      from Early Show Anchor, Harry Smith, in for Anchor and Managing Editor 
      Katie Couric who is on assignment... Good afternoon, 
      After a week of floods and fires across the United States, 
      Catalina Island off Los Angeles has become the latest wildfire victim. 
      Throughout the night, thousands of residents and visitors fled the 
      island’s main town under an evacuation order. Bill Whitaker will 
      report on the devastating blaze and citizens’ dramatic nighttime escapes. 
      Meanwhile, Sharyl Attkisson is on Capitol Hill with some 
      exclusive information about what might be the best chance for all sides to 
      work out a last-ditch immigration reform deal. On the state level, 
      legislation is being considered in several states that could affect the 
      lives of teens and the tech-dependent. Sandra Hughes will report 
      that Washington state and New Jersey could both ban text messaging while 
      driving. Considering the statistics – teenagers say text messaging is 
      their biggest driving distraction – more states could follow suit. 
      It is graduation day at Virginia Tech, and today’s ceremonies will 
      be part commencement and part remembrance. Sharyn Alfonsi is on 
      campus and will have the story. There is also a unique graduation 
      story at Fort Hays University in Kansas. For Assignment 
      America, Steve Hartman will introduce 
      you to one woman who took the advice “it’s never too late to follow your 
      dreams.” Now she’s becoming the country’s oldest person to be graduated by 
      a college. Join us tonight for this and more. Harry
For more on two of the stories noted above, please click on the

      Bittersweet Graduation Click Here Here's an early look 
      a series we are working on that focuses on marketing machine that is 
      targeting your children. Starting Monday on the CBS Evening NewsFrom 
      books, to toys to clothes to snacks. There's a multi-billion dollar, 
      global marketing machine targeting YOUR children. Our special series, " 
      GOTTA HAVE IT: THE HARD SELL TO KIDS " beginning Monday, on the CBS 
      Evening News. THIS WEEKEND ON THE CBS EVENING NEWS: 
      SATURDAY ON THE CBS EVENING NEWS… Thalia Assuras will anchor the Saturday edition of the CBS 
      Evening News in New York. We'll have the latest news, including 
      these stories: VA TECH GRADUATION: Sharyn Alfonsi reports from 
      the commencement exercises at Virginia Tech, the site of last month's 
      shooting spree. POPE IN BRAZIL: Pope Benedict XVI continues 
      his history-making trip to the largest Catholic country in the world. 
      Allen Pizzey reports. STEALTH CANDIDATES PART 1: 
      Many Democrats and Republicans are looking beyond the current field of 
      presidential candidates to two men that may find themselves in the race 
      before the end of the year. In the first of two reports on these so-called 
      "Stealth Candidates,” Thalia Assuras looks at the momentum building 
      behind former U.S. Senator Fred Thompson. MERCURY 13: The 
      Mercury 7 astronauts are known in history for having "the right stuff." 
      But there's another group of test pilots who played an important role in 
      the early days of NASA. They are the Mercury 13, a group of women that 
      Randall Pinkston reports is finally being recognized for their 
      contribution to the U.S. space program. SWITCH PITCHER: 
      Switch hitters are nothing new to baseball. But a college athlete is 
      throwing the sport a curve by pitching from both sides of the mound. 
      Hari Sreenivasan introduces us to an unusual switch PITCHER. 
      SUNDAY ON THE CBS EVENING NEWS… Russ Mitchell will anchor the Sunday edition of the CBS Evening 
      News in New York. We'll have the latest news, including these 
      stories: STEALTH CANDIDATES PART 2: The second of our reports 
      on "Stealth Candidates" looks at the intriguing possibility of Al Gore 
      throwing his hat in the ring. Bill Whitaker reports. 
      FEEDING CHILDREN: On this World Hunger Day, Allen 
      Pizzey reports on efforts to feed the starving in Darfur. A 
      ROSE BLOOMS: Many Americans give their mom a rose for Mother's Day. 
      But some of those roses are from overseas farms that pay workers pennies a 
      day or use potentially hazardous chemicals. Anthony Mason reports 
      on one Central American farmer who insists on doing right by his workers 
      and his flowers -- even if it costs him. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 
      

TONIGHT ON DAVID LETTERMAN Dave chats with 
      actor Charles Grodin AND comedian Jake Johanssen! 

TOMORROW ON THE 
      SATURDAY EARLY SHOW Tracy Smith and Chris 
      Wragge of our New York affiliate, WCBS, anchor THE SATURDAY 
      EARLY SHOW from New York. Ira Joe 
      Fisher will bring us the weather. Along 
      with the top news of the day, we will also have the following stories: 
      JAMESTOWN: The first permanent English settlement in North 
      America turns 400 this weekend, and our Russ Mitchell will be there 
      to talk with archaeologist William Kelso. Since uncovering the original 
      Jamestown fort in 1994, Kelso and his team have discovered one million 
      pieces of evidence in the soil, giving Americans a richer understanding of 
      the first successful colony. Kelso will join us with some of the artifacts 
      he’s found so far. HEALTHWATCH – SCREENINGS: There are five 
      essential medical tests everyone should have to help prevent health 
      problems. Dr. Mallika Marshall will tell us about these top five 
      screenings and when it’s necessary to schedule them. TRAVEL 
      GADGETS: From a compact photo printer to a water bottle that doubles 
      as a flashlight, Technology Correspondent Daniel Sieberg will show 
      us all sorts of cool gadgets to make your travels more convenient and more 
      enjoyable. MOTHER’S DAY CHOCOLATES: Jacques Torres knows a 
      thing or two about chocolate. The master pastry chef has won prestigious 
      culinary awards both in France and the U.S. He'll be on our plaza this 
      Mother's Day weekend to show us how to choose the best chocolates, and 
      he’ll even show us how to make chocolate lollipops at home. 
      STAMP OUT HUNGER: Letter carriers all across the U.S. will 
      collect food for the hungry this weekend, picking up donations right from 
      the doorstep of people on their routes. We'll hear about it from William 
      Young of the National Association of Letter Carriers. Eugene "Killer" 
      Edgerson of The Harlem Globetrotters will be on hand to drum up support 
      for the food drive, while some of his teammates shoot hoops with our 
      anchors. GAS GRILLS: If you're looking to upgrade your gas 
      grill, you'll find the choices are better than ever, and Consumer 
      Reports has rated this season's best buys. Our resident handyman and 
      host of Today's Homeowner, Danny Lipford, will join us with 
      his top picks for this year. CELEBRITY DISH: This week, we 
      introduce a new feature in which Jill Dobson of Star Magazine 
      brings us up-to-date on the entertainment stories that everyone will be 
      buzzing about. CHEF ON A SHOESTRING: Debra Ponzek is an 
      award-winning chef, cookbook author and mom. She's making what she 
      believes is the IDEAL Mother's Day meal -- a menu she would like her 
      family to serve her for Mother's Day. SECOND CUP CAFE: A 
      longtime favorite in the country-music world, Montgomery Gentry could add 
      more awards to their collection at Tuesday night's Academy of Country 
      Music Awards, which will be broadcast on CBS. We'll hear songs from their 
      latest CD, Some People Change. To look for our fabulous 
      recipes... Click Here If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: sat@cbsnews.com 
      

HERE'S WHAT WE HAVE PLANNED FOR SUNDAY 
      MORNING CHARLES OSGOOD ANCHORS FROM 
      NEW YORK MODEL LIFE: Correspondent Russ Mitchell 
      reports on the changing history of the "cover girl." JOSH 
      GROBAN: Josh Groban's lyrical voice has made him a rising star. He was 
      just 20 when he released his first album of ballads and love songs. Now 
      26, he's sold more than 16 million records with hits like the uplifting 
      "You Raise Me Up." Correspondent Sandra Hughes introduces us to 
      Josh Groban in this Sunday Morning 
      Profile. http://www.joshgroban.com Click Here http://www.repriserecords.com Click 
      Here UNLEASHED!: Bill Berloni has 
      been discovering Broadway stars for thirty years- all at local animal 
      shelters. Martha Teichner explores this veteran dog trainer's 
      casting techniques and how all his star pupils are making their come-back. 
      ART: They were called "Moving Pictures." The earliest films 
      really were more like "art that moved" than the plot-based "movies" of 
      today. Nancy Mowll Mathews spent 10 years collecting examples that 
      illustrate just how much painters and sculptors influenced early 
      filmmakers--and vice versa. The exhibit she created called Moving 
      Pictures, shows in a very dramatic way, the extraordinary connection 
      between art and early films. 
      http://www.phillipscollection.org/html/exhibits.html Click Here NASCAR MOMS: 40 
      weeks a year, NASCAR - the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing - 
      brings its unique brand of traveling circus to a speedway near you. But 
      for all the beer and baseball caps, a NASCAR is a surprisingly 
      female-friendly affair. NASCAR says that in the past three years, the 
      male-dominated circuit has seen a big surge in female fans. Why? Women say 
      they like the drivers, the family-friendly atmosphere...and the 
      ear-shattering sound. Tracy Smith takes us on a lap around NASCAR. 
      WAY OFF THE ROAD: For the past 20 years, Bill Geist 
      has been criss-crossing America for Sunday 
      Morning, searching for the wackiest and most 
      wonderful people, places and things he could find. He's written a new book 
      about his adventures, and Bill's hands-on approach to book-selling turned 
      into quite an adventure in its own right. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: sundays@cbsnews.com 
      

SUNDAY ON FACE THE 
      NATION This Sunday on Face the 
      Nation, Bob Schieffer will talk to 
      Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska about war and politics. Will Republicans 
      keep supporting President Bush on the war? Will there be a deal on funding 
      for the war? And is he running for President? All questions for Senator 
      Hagel. Then we'll get all the rest of the week's political news from 
      Jeanne Cummings of the Politico.com and Michael Martin of NPR. There will 
      be, as always, a final word. That's all on Face the 
      Nation, this Sunday. 

SUNDAY ON 60 
      MINUTES, 7:00PM/6:00PM CT MITT ROMNEY: The 
      Republican presidential candidate talks to Mike Wallace about 
      campaign issues including the war in Iraq, his Mormon religion and his 
      changing positions on abortion. 6%: Realtors' sacrosanct 
      commission rate of 6 percent may be in jeopardy due to emerging online 
      competition from Internet real estate sellers and buyers. Lesley 
      Stahl reports. ALI: Bob Simon catches up with Iraqi war 
      orphan Ali Abbas, who lost most of his family and his arms to a stray 
      American bomb during the war in Iraq. 

MONDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW Harry Smith, 
      Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor THE EARLY 
      SHOW from New York. Hannah Storm 
      anchors from Las Vegas, NV. Dave Price will bring us the weather. 
      Along with the top news of the day, we will also have the 
      following stories: CARRIE UNDERWOOD: Almost two years 
      ago, aspiring country singer Carrie Underwood battled it out with rocker 
      Bo Bice to see who would be named the fourth American Idol. In the 
      time since, the Oklahoma native has become a true country star. Her debut 
      CD, Some Hearts, went triple platinum, earning her two number one 
      hit singles and a nomination for album of the year in the Academy of 
      Country Music Awards. Carrie will join us live from Las Vegas Monday 
      morning. GOTTA HAVE IT: THE HARD SELL TO KIDS: ALPHA KIDS: 
      We begin a special series on THE EARLY SHOW and continuing on the CBS EVENING NEWS, Gotta Have It: The Hard Sell to Kids. Companies are using 
      a marketing method to make billions of dollars off of you and your 
      children. Are they going too far? Monday morning, we take a look at GIA, 
      the Girls Intelligence Agency, a marketing firm that is using a 
      multi-million dollar strategy aimed at children. Is choosing 
      eight-year-old girls as test subjects a case of viral marketing gone 
      wrong? If one young girl, chosen by the company, likes a product, it 
      follows that she will tell her friends, who will tell their friends, and 
      so on. But what are the dangers of tweens predicting and being influenced 
      by these companies? Monday morning, EARLY SHOW National Correspondent Tracy Smith will take a look in the 
      first part of our special series. IN DR. PHIL'S HOUSE: CHILD 
      STARS: In an age of reality TV and Youtube, it seems that everyone 
      wants to be famous- and if they can't be, then some parents push their 
      children toward stardom. To take a look at this phenomenon, Dr. Phil 
      McGraw is debuting a new series on his talk show Monday called Child 
      Stars. He brings together five families whose mothers want more than 
      anything for their kids to become famous. Dr. Phil will join us Monday 
      morning to get a sneak preview of his look into children and showbiz. 
      SURVIVOR WINNER AND CHECK PRESENTATION: Stranded in Fiji, 
      the competition heats up for the remaining survivors battling it out for 
      the million-dollar prize. In the two-hour two hundredth episode of 
      Survivor, five tribemates battle it out for the title of Soul 
      Survivor. Monday morning, we will present the winner with their 
      million-dollar check live on our plaza! MIRANDA LAMBERT: 
      When it comes to telling it like it is, country singer/songwriter Miranda 
      Lambert certainly has a way with words! Her fiery hot single, 
      Kerosene, from her 2005 debut quickly heated up the charts and now 
      her sophomore project promises much of the same. Her gossipy new song, 
      Famous in a Small Town, has everybody talking and is the first 
      single off her sophomore release, Crazy Ex-Girlfriend, which just 
      entered the charts at number one. Our own Hannah Storm will get 
      Miranda’s take on being famous. BILL GEIST: WAY OFF THE 
      ROAD: For twenty years, Bill Geist has delivered the big news 
      from some of America's smallest towns. And, the Correspondent best known 
      for his reporting for CBS News' Sunday Morning, has often taken us on quite an adventure. From flying with a 
      paperboy pilot, to challenging a watermelon champion speed eater, these 
      exploits and many more are featured in Bill's new book, Way Off The 
      Road: The Peculiar Charms of Small-Town America. Monday morning, Bill 
      will join us for more on his adventures and his latest book. 
      DAVID EVANGELISTA: SUMMER HAIR: For the latest ways to keep 
      cool this summer, it doesn’t matter if your hair is naturally curly or 
      wavy, everyone can achieve sleek, smooth and straight summer hair. Maybe 
      if your hair is straight, the summer has put you in the mood to try 
      something new and different? For all the latest in hair looks, we’ll turn 
      to our stylist to the stars, David Evangelista, Monday morning. 
      KELLI PICKLER: Kelli Pickler's red high heels have taken 
      her all the way to the ACM Awards. This year, the American Idol 
      finalist is up for Top New Female vocalist for her debut album Small 
      Town Girl. Live from Las Vegas, our own Hannah Storm will find 
      out what a year it has been for her. Then, Kelli will dazzle us with what 
      is sure to be an amazing performance! If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
